lead_paragraph: WikiLeaks.org, the online organization that posted tens of thousands of classified military field reports about the Afghan war on Sunday, says its goal in disclosing secret documents is to reveal ''unethical behavior'' by governments and corporations. Since it was founded in December 2006, WikiLeaks has exposed internal memos about the dumping of toxic material off the African coast, the membership rolls of a racist British party, and the American military's manual for operating its prison in Guantánamo Bay, Cuba.

headline.main: In Disclosing Secret Documents, WikiLeaks Seeks 'Transparency'

abstract: WikiLeaks, which published online tens of thousands of classified military field reports about Afghan war, says its goal in disclosing secret documents is to reveal 'unethical behavior' by governments and corporations; photo (M)
snippet: An online organization wants to combat “unethical behavior” by governments and corporations, but critics say it endangers the privacy of others for the sake of self-promotion.

keywords.name: subject
keywords.value: UNITED STATES DEFENSE AND MILITARY FORCES

lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON -- The White House sought to reassert control over the public debate on the Afghanistan war on Monday as political reaction to the disclosure of a six-year archive of classified military documents increased pressure on President Obama to defend his war strategy. On Capitol Hill, a leading Senate Democrat said the documents, with their detailed account of a war faring even more poorly than two administrations had portrayed, would intensify Congressional scrutiny of Mr. Obama's policy.

headline.main: Document Leak Adds to Pressure On White House

abstract: White House seeks to reassert control over public debate on Afghanistan war as political reaction to disclosure of six-year archive of classified military documents increases pressure on Pres Obama to defend his war strategy; inside administration more officials are privately questioning policy; House leaders in Congress are rushing to hold vote on critical war-financing bill, fearing that disclosures could stoke Democratic opposition to measure; administration officials acknowledge that documents, released on Internet by Wikileaks, will make it harder for Obama as he tries to hang on to public and Congressional support; he must decide whether to convince Congress and American people that his war strategy remains on track, or move more quickly toward more limited American presence; photos (M)
snippet: Political reaction to the disclosure of classified documents increased the pressure on President Obama to defend his war strategy as a war-financing bill looms.

keywords.name: subject
keywords.value: UNITED STATES DEFENSE AND MILITARY FORCES

byline.original: By ERIC SCHMITT  and HELENE COOPER; Adam B. Ellick and Salman Masood contributed reporting from Islamabad, Pakistan, and Richard A. Oppel Jr. from Kabul, Afghanistan

lead_paragraph: Washington ANYONE who has spent the past two days reading through the 92,000 military field reports and other documents made public by the whistle-blower site WikiLeaks may be forgiven for wondering what all the fuss is about. I'm a researcher who studies Afghanistan and have no regular access to classified information, yet I have seen nothing in the documents that has either surprised me or told me anything of significance. I suspect that's the case even for someone who reads only a third of the articles on Afghanistan in his local newspaper.

headline.main: Getting Lost in the Fog of War

abstract: Andrew Exum Op-Ed article reviews major revelations in military field reports made public by WikiLeaks; contends that nothing in documents is either surprising or significant; scores leaks as reckless and destructive, and holds that WikiLeaks founder Julian Assange, self-proclaimed journalist, is merely muddying waters between journalism and activism (M)
snippet: The WikiLeaks documents don’t add to our understanding of the Afghan war — they further confuse a complex conflict.

keywords.name: subject
keywords.value: UNITED STATES DEFENSE AND MILITARY FORCES

lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON -- The Pentagon is reviewing tens of thousands of classified battlefield reports made public this week about the war in Afghanistan to determine whether Afghan informants were identified and could be at risk of reprisals, American officials said Wednesday. A Pentagon spokesman, Col. David Lapan, said that a Pentagon assessment team had not yet drawn any conclusions, but that ''in general, the naming of individuals could cause potential problems, both to their physical safety or willingness to continue support to coalition forces or the Afghan government.''

headline.main: Pentagon Studies Risks to Afghans From Leaks

abstract: American officials say Pentagon is reviewing tens of thousands of classified battlefield reports made public about war in Afghanistan to determine whether Afghan informants were identified and could be at risk of reprisals; Pentagon says assessment team has not yet drawn any conclusions, but that leaks could jeopardize informants' safety or their willingness to cooperate with coalition efforts; review of sampling of documents released by organization WikiLeaks finds reports that name dozens of Afghans credited with providing credible information to American and NATO troops; WikiLeaks founder Julian Assange says organization withheld 15,000 of approximately 92,000 documents in archive that was released to remove names of informants; but 75,000 documents WikiLeaks posted online provide information about possible informants, like their villages and in some cases their fathers' names; national security officials are worried that attention WikiLeaks has received has elevated its profile and could be used to entice disgruntled officials to send classified information to its Web site; government lawyers are reportedly exploring whether WikiLeaks and Assange could be prosecuted for making documents public (M)
snippet: Some of the documents released by WikiLeaks contain the names of Afghans who gave information to NATO troops.

keywords.name: subject
keywords.value: UNITED STATES DEFENSE AND MILITARY FORCES

byline.original: By ERIC SCHMITT and CHARLIE SAVAGE; Andrew W. Lehren contributed research from New York

lead_paragraph: THE four stages of a political movement, as Gandhi told it, were: ''First they ignore you, then they laugh at you, then they fight you, then you win.'' For the whistle-blower Web site WikiLeaks, the release last week of secret field reports on the war in Afghanistan that it obtained from American military sources certainly looked like a victory. Not only did The New York Times, The Guardian and Der Spiegel devote hundreds of hours of reporters' and editors' time to analyzing and confirming the information in the documents, the three agreed to coordinate publication for last Monday, ensuring there would be blanket news media coverage on at least two continents.

headline.main: A Renegade Site, Now Working With the News Media

abstract: Noam Cohen Link by Link column discusses strategy shift at WikiLeaks in wake of its release of secret reports on Afghanistan war; points out site, by handing over documents to professional news media with no strings attached, and before it could offer its own interpretation, is becoming information procurer rather than information explainer; photo (M)
snippet: WikiLeaks was criticized for its previous coup, a video of soldiers in Iraq killing civilians. This time, it let journalists parse the information.

keywords.name: subject
keywords.value: UNITED STATES DEFENSE AND MILITARY FORCES

lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON -- The Pentagon demanded on Thursday that WikiLeaks ''do the right thing'' and remove from its Web site tens of thousands of classified documents about the war in Afghanistan, and return to the military thousands of others that it had not yet made public. Geoff Morrell, the Pentagon press secretary, said the Web site's disclosure last week of a six-year archive of some 77,000 documents gave the Taliban and other militant groups insights into American military tactics and techniques, showed how the United States protects its troops in war zones and revealed the names of Afghan informants and how the military cultivates them.

headline.main: Return Unseen War Logs, Pentagon Tells WikiLeaks

abstract: Pentagon demands that Wikileaks 'do the right thing' and remove from its Web site tens of thousands of classified documents about war in Afghanistan, and return to military thousands of others that it has not yet made public; photo of WikiLeaks founder Julian Assange (M)
snippet: The Pentagon demanded that WikiLeaks “do the right thing” and remove classified documents from its Web site.

keywords.name: subject
keywords.value: UNITED STATES DEFENSE AND MILITARY FORCES

byline.original: By ERIC SCHMITT; Charlie Savage contributed reporting

lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON -- The Pentagon on Wednesday rebutted statements by the WikiLeaks organization that the Defense Department had expressed a willingness to discuss reviewing a trove of classified documents before public release. ''The Department of Defense will not negotiate some 'minimized' or 'sanitized' version of a release by WikiLeaks of additional U.S. government classified documents,'' Jeh C. Johnson, the Pentagon general counsel, wrote in a letter to a lawyer representing WikiLeaks, the online whistle-blowing organization. The letter was dated Monday but was provided by Defense Department officials on Wednesday.

headline.main: WikiLeaks And Pentagon Disagree About Talks

abstract: Pentagon rebuts statements by WikiLeaks that Defense Department expressed willingness to discuss reviewing trove of classified documents before public release (S)
snippet: In a letter to a lawyer representing the online organization, the Defense Department’s general counsel wrote that the department would not negotiate a new release of classified documents.

keywords.name: subject
keywords.value: UNITED STATES DEFENSE AND MILITARY FORCES

lead_paragraph: LONDON -- Julian Assange, the founder of the WikiLeaks Web site who is embroiled in a fight with the Pentagon over the disclosure of secret military documents, was caught up in a new drama on Saturday when Swedish prosecutors sought him for questioning on allegations of rape and molestation -- and then announced the rape allegation was unfounded. The abrupt reversal marked another strange twist to Mr. Assange's already complicated tale. A 39-year-old former computer hacker from Australia, Mr. Assange has become ever more elusive in recent weeks as the Obama administration hinted it might prosecute him for releasing about 77,000 classified Afghan war documents on the Internet last month. His confrontation with the administration has grown only more bitter as he warned that the organization would soon release 15,000 more documents.

headline.main: Sweden Adds To Drama Over Founder Of WikiLeaks

abstract: Swedish prosecutors say they are seeking WikiLeaks founder Julian Assange, whose whereabouts are unknown, for questioning over allegations of rape and molestation, but then abruptly call rape allegation unfounded; Assange denies charges, saying they are payback for his exposure of classified information; bizarre episode has raised doubts about Assange's apparent strategy to make permanent home in Sweden (M)
snippet: Julian Assange was sought by Swedish prosecutors for questioning on rape allegations, but the prosecutors then said the accusations were unfounded.

byline.original: By JOHN F. BURNS  and ERIC SCHMITT; John F. Burns reported from London, and Eric Schmitt from Washington. Charlie Savage contributed reporting from Washington, Ravi Somaiya from London, and Liz Robbins from New York

lead_paragraph: STOCKHOLM -- The Swedish prosecutor's office on Sunday defended its handling of allegations made by two Swedish women against Julian Assange, founder of the WikiLeaks Web site, saying that a senior prosecutor withdrew the arrest warrant that had been issued for Mr. Assange on a rape charge after reviewing a judgment made by a more junior official before additional information became available. The abrupt reversal of the prosecutor's office had added a new and bizarre turn to events involving Mr. Assange, a 39-year-old Australian. He has been locked in a dispute with the Pentagon over WikiLeaks' posting last month of 77,000 classified Afghan war documents on the Internet, and its announcement of plans within weeks to post 15,000 additional secret documents that he has described as even ''more explosive.''

headline.main: Sweden Defends Reversal On Founder of WikiLeaks

abstract: Swedish prosecutor's office defends its handling of rape and molestation allegations made by two Swedish women against WikiLeaks founder Julian Assange; says that senior prosecutor withdrew arrest warrant after additional information on case became available; abrupt reversal adds new and bizarre turn to events involving Assange; photo (M)
snippet: Swedish prosecutors said that they had made no mistakes in issuing an arrest warrant for Julian Assange, the founder of WikiLeaks, and withdrawing it hours later.

byline.original: By JOHN F. BURNS; William Rankin contributed reporting from New York, Eric Schmitt from Washington and Ravi Somaiya from London

lead_paragraph: STOCKHOLM -- Although Swedish prosecutors have yet to complete their review of sexual abuse accusations that two Stockholm women made last week against Julian Assange, founder of the WikiLeaks Web site, those who say they have detailed knowledge of the case discount conspiracy theories linking it to efforts to discredit WikiLeaks. Mr. Assange had suggested over the weekend that the tortured sequence of events at the Stockholm prosecutor's office had been prompted by the Pentagon as part of what he called a program of ''dirty tricks to ruin us.'' The prosecutors had issued a warrant for Mr. Assange's arrest on suspicion of rape on Friday night, which was followed within 24 hours by the cancellation of the warrant and a formal retraction of the implication that a rape had occurred.

headline.main: Plotting Doubted in Case Facing WikiLeaks Founder

abstract: Insiders who say they have detailed knowledge of Swedish prosecutors' sexual abuse accusations against WikiLeaks founder Julian Assange discount conspiracy theories linking it to efforts to discredit his Web site; Assange, whose warrant for arrest on suspicion of rape was followed by cancellation of warrant and formal retraction, has suggested that sequence of events had been prompted by Pentagon (M)
snippet: Those who have knowledge of Swedish prosecutors’ sexual abuse accusations against Julian Assange discount conspiracy theories linking it to efforts to discredit WikiLeaks.

lead_paragraph: STOCKHOLM -- The bid by Julian Assange, founder of the WikiLeaks whistle-blower Web site, to find a secure base in Sweden appeared to have been complicated on Wednesday by a Swedish prosecutor, who ordered the police to question Mr. Assange about accusations of molesting made against him by two Swedish women. Eva Finne, chief prosecutor in Stockholm, said she had taken the step after reviewing police files in the case. In an interview at the prosecutors' offices in central Stockholm, she said there was enough in the women's complaints to require formal questioning of Mr. Assange, whose accounts of his relationships with the women has been limited to e-mails and telephone conversations with reporters and friends.

headline.main: Sweden to Question Founder of WikiLeaks

abstract: Swedish prosecutor Eva Finne orders police to question WikiLeaks founder Julian Assange about accusations of molesting made against him by two Swedish women; move comes after several days in which Assange and his lawyer had expressed frustration that police had not sought out his version of events (M)
snippet: A Swedish prosecutor ordered the police to question Julian Assange, founder of the WikiLeaks whistle-blower Web site, about accusations of molesting.

lead_paragraph: PARIS -- The Swedish authorities announced Wednesday that they were reopening an investigation of rape allegations against Julian Assange, the founder of the WikiLeaks Web site, saying there was ''reason to believe that a crime has been committed.'' The announcement by Marianne Ny, director of public prosecution, was another reversal in the convoluted case. Last month, Swedish prosecutors confirmed that they had issued an arrest warrant for Mr. Assange on rape and molestation allegations, but dropped the rape charge after saying it was unfounded.

headline.main: Sweden Reopens Rape Investigation of WikiLeaks Founder

abstract: Sweden reopens investigation of rape and molestation allegations by two women and issue arrest warrant for WikiLeaks founder Julian Assange; women say they had consensual sex with Assange that became nonconsensual (M)
snippet: Swedish authorities said they reopened an investigation of rape allegations against Julian Assange.

byline.original: By DAVID JOLLY; John F. Burns contributed reporting from Stockholm, and William Rankin from Paris

lead_paragraph: LONDON -- A prominent spokesman for WikiLeaks announced his resignation on Monday in an interview with a German news magazine, marking the latest in a series of public rifts within the organization. Daniel Domscheit-Berg, 32, told the magazine Der Spiegel that increasing tensions with the Web site's founder and figurehead, Julian Assange, had left him with no option but ''an orderly departure.''

headline.main: Spokesman For WikiLeaks Steps Down

abstract: WikiLeaks spokesman Daniel Domscheit-Berg resigns, citing increasing tensions with WikiLeaks founder Julian Assange (M)
snippet: Daniel Domscheit-Berg told a German news magazine that increasing tensions with the Web site’s founder had left him with no option but “an orderly departure.”

lead_paragraph: LONDON -- Julian Assange, the WikiLeaks founder, and Daniel Ellsberg, who leaked the Pentagon Papers, lashed out together on Saturday at the Obama administration's aggressive pursuit of whistle-blowers, including those responsible for the release of secret documents on the Iraq war. Mr. Assange also said that WikiLeaks, which released the trove of almost 400,000 Iraq war documents on Friday, would shortly be posting an additional 15,000 remaining secret documents on the Afghan war.

headline.main: Leaker of Pentagon Papers Joins WikiLeaks Founder in Rebuking U.S.

abstract: WikiLeaks founder Julian Assange holds London new conference with Daniel Ellsberg, who leaked Pentagon Papers in 1971; Ellsberg blasts Obama administration for its aggressive pursuit of whistle-blowers; Assange disparages Defense Department's efforts to minimize effect of release of Iraq war documents; photo (M)
snippet: Julian Assange and Daniel Ellsberg, who leaked the Pentagon Papers, lashed out at the Obama administration’s aggressive pursuit of whistle-blowers.

byline.original: By JOHN F. BURNS and RAVI SOMAIYA

lead_paragraph: LONDON -- Julian Assange moves like a hunted man. In a noisy Ethiopian restaurant in London's rundown Paddington district, he pitches his voice barely above a whisper to foil the Western intelligence agencies he fears. He demands that his dwindling number of loyalists use expensive encrypted cellphones and swaps his own as other men change shirts. He checks into hotels under false names, dyes his hair, sleeps on sofas and floors, and uses cash instead of credit cards, often borrowed from friends.

headline.main: Iraq Archive: Private Gunmen Fed Turmoil: WikiLeaks Chief On Run, Trailed By His Notoriety

abstract: WikiLeaks founder Julian Assange has been living on run since Web site's release of classified documents on Afghan and Iraq wars; some of his own comrades are abandoning him, citing erratic and imperious behavior that is unchecked by awareness of human costs of secrets he reveals; photo (M)
snippet: Julian Assange is used to being denounced, but now some of his own comrades are abandoning him for what they see as erratic and imperious behavior.

keywords.name: subject
keywords.value: UNITED STATES DEFENSE AND MILITARY FORCES

byline.original: By JOHN F. BURNS and RAVI SOMAIYA; Eric Schmitt contributed reporting from Washington, and Dexter Filkins from Kabul, Afghanistan

lead_paragraph: To the Editor: Re ''The Iraq Archive: The Strands of a War'' (''The War Logs,'' front page, Oct. 23):

headline.main: The Iraq Files: Lessons and Questions

snippet: Responses to “The War Logs” articles about the trove of secret field reports from Iraq obtained by the group WikiLeaks.

keywords.name: subject
keywords.value: UNITED STATES DEFENSE AND MILITARY FORCES

lead_paragraph: THE two stories stood side by side: one said that Julian Assange, the founder of WikiLeaks, was on the run, in fear of Western intelligence agencies and seen by some colleagues as ''delusional,'' ''erratic'' and ''imperious.'' The other story? A chilling account of war in Iraq, for which Mr. Assange and his organization were the primary source. In publishing its latest installment of ''The War Logs,'' which appeared in print last Saturday and Sunday, The Times confronted a stark duality. The case for reporting on nearly 400,000 classified documents was compelling, while the character of its primary source appeared increasingly sketchy.

headline.main: Sharing Secrets at Arm's Length

abstract: Arthur S Brisbane Public Editor column examines the decision by the New York Times to publish classified documents provided to the paper by WikiLeaks; asserts that the Times did the right thing (M)
snippet: Among The Times’s challenges in handling the “War Logs”: keeping distance between itself and WikiLeaks.

keywords.name: subject
keywords.value: UNITED STATES DEFENSE AND MILITARY FORCES

lead_paragraph: LONDON -- The Swedish prosecutor's office said Thursday that a court in Stockholm had approved its request for arrest warrants to be issued for Julian Assange, founder of the WikiLeaks Web site, for questioning on charges of rape and other sexual offenses. Mr. Assange has strongly denied the accusations. Marianne Ny, director of the Stockholm prosecutor's office, said in a statement that she had moved to have Mr. Assange extradited to Sweden on suspicion of ''rape, sexual molestation and unlawful coercion.'' The accusations were first made against Mr. Assange, 39, an Australian who created the whistle-blowers' site, after he traveled to Sweden in mid-August and had brief relationships with two Swedish women that he has described as consensual.

headline.main: Sweden Seeks Arrest of WikiLeaks Chief in Rape Case

snippet: The Swedish prosecutor’s office said that Julian Assange is being sought for questioning on months-old charges of rape and other offenses.

byline.original: By JOHN F. BURNS and RAVI SOMAIYA; Ravi Somaiya contributed reporting

lead_paragraph: DealBook has been admiring our Times colleagues' State's Secrets series, a collection of articles about the trove of American diplomatic cables that were originally obtained by WikiLeaks, the organization devoted to exposing state secrets.

headline.main: Next WikiLeaks Target: Big Business

abstract: Julian Assange, the founder of WikiLeaks, told Forbes magazine that his Web site is planning to release tens of thousands of documents from a major American financial firm in early 2011.
snippet: Julian Assange, the founder of WikiLeaks, told Forbes magazine that his Web site is planning to release tens of thousands of documents from a major American financial firm in early 2011.

lead_paragraph: Julian Assange, the founder of WikiLeaks, had moved 37 times by the time he reached his 14th birthday. His mother didn't enroll him in the local schools because, as Raffi Khatchadourian wrote in a New Yorker profile, she feared ''that formal education would inculcate an unhealthy respect for authority.'' She needn't have worried. As a young computer hacker, he formed a group called International Subversives. As an adult, he wrote ''Conspiracy as Governance,'' a pseudo-intellectual online diatribe. He talks of vast ''patronage networks'' that constrain the human spirit.

headline.main: The Fragile Community

abstract: David Brooks Op-Ed column holds that true damage of WikiLeaks information dump is impact it will have on quantity and quality of fragile international conversation; argues that private, trustworthy conversations are what allow all of humanity to live amid order and not chaos; says media and Internet must find ways to report on specific information without unveiling and undermining nuts and bolts of diplomatic enterprise itself (M)
snippet: After another dump from WikiLeaks, making a case for greater diplomatic privacy.

lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON -- Calls to prosecute the founder of WikiLeaks, Julian Assange, mounted this week as his organization began releasing documents from a cache of 250,000 State Department cables -- its third major disclosure of United States government secrets this year. Attorney General Eric H. Holder Jr. has confirmed that the Justice Department is examining whether Mr. Assange could be charged with a crime, but legal scholars say that such an effort would encounter steep legal and policy difficulties.

headline.main: U.S. Weighs Prosecution of WikiLeaks Founder, but Legal Scholars Warn of Steep Hurdles

abstract: United States Atty Gen Eric H Holder Jr confirms that Justice Department is examining whether Julian Assange, founder of WikiLeaks, can be charged with crime; US has only prosecuted government officials responsible for leaking document, not outsiders who received information and passed it on; photo (M)
snippet: Attorney General Eric H. Holder Jr. has confirmed that the Justice Department is examining whether Julian Assange could be charged with a crime.

lead_paragraph: LONDON -- For nearly two weeks, Interpol has been circulating a broad international call for the arrest of Julian Assange, the founder of the WikiLeaks whistle-blowing organization, to face questioning about alleged sex crimes, Interpol said on its Web site on Wednesday. Also on Wednesday, WikiLeaks accused Amazon.com of ending an agreement to host its Web site. Amazon hosts the sites of many companies and organizations as part of its Amazon Web Services program.

headline.main: Interpol Calls for WikiLeaks Founder's Arrest in Connection With Swedish Cases

abstract: Interpol calls for arrest of Julian Assange, founder of WikiLeaks whistle-blowing operation, to face questioning about alleged sex crimes in Sweden; photo (M)
snippet: Interpol has for two weeks been circulating a call for the arrest of Julian Assange on sex crimes charges.

byline.original: By JOHN F. BURNS and ALAN COWELL; John F. Burns reported from London, and Alan Cowell from Paris. Ravi Somaiya contributed reporting from London, and Verne G. Kopytoff from San Francisco

lead_paragraph: LONDON -- Sweden's highest court refused on Thursday to allow Julian Assange, the founder of the WikiLeaks whistle-blowing organization, to appeal a court order seeking his arrest to face questioning over alleged sex crimes, his lawyer and said. In a telephone interview, Mark Stephens, Mr. Assange's lawyer in Britain, said the ruling by the Stockholm court exhausted his client's legal options in trying to overturn the arrest order in Sweden, where the offenses are alleged to have taken place. Thursday's ruling came a day after Interpol, the global police body, said it had been circulating a so-called Red Notice seeking Mr. Assange's arrest for almost two weeks. Reuters quoted Kerstin Norman, a Swedish High Court official, as saying the ruling meant that earlier warrants for Mr. Assange's arrest were still in force.

headline.main: Swedish Court Confirms Arrest Warrant for WikiLeaks Founder

snippet: Sweden’s highest court refused on Thursday to grant permission for Julian Assange to appeal an arrest order in a sex crimes case.

byline.original: By JOHN F. BURNS and ALAN COWELL; John F. Burns reported from London, and Alan Cowell from Paris. Ravi Somaiya contributed reporting from London, and Verne G. Kopytoff from San Francisco

lead_paragraph: One big lesson from the WikiLeaks dump of state department documents: Weddings in Dagestan are insanely awesome.

headline.main: The Hunt for Julian Assange

abstract: Would prosecuting Wikileaks for spilling secrets be possible -- or smart?
snippet: Would prosecuting Wikileaks for spilling secrets be possible -- or smart?

lead_paragraph: LONDON -- As the political storm over their release of 250,000 secret American diplomatic cables continues, the WikiLeaks Web site and its founder, Julian Assange, are facing new legal and operational challenges from Swedish prosecutors and from one of the online payment services that have been used to channel donations to the whistle-blowing organization. PayPal, one of the most widely used online payment services, severed ties to WikiLeaks, following similar moves by the e-commerce Web site Amazon and the domain name company EveryDNS.net. In a statement dated Friday, PayPal said that it had ''permanently restricted the account used by WikiLeaks.''

headline.main: New Obstacles Spring Up For WikiLeaks and Founder

abstract: PayPal has joined Internet companies severing ties to WikiLeaks; Swedish authorities reissue European warrant for WikiLeaks founder Julian Assange's arrest and extradition for questioning in regard to alleged sexual improprieties in Sweden (M)
snippet: PayPal, one of the most widely used online payment services, severed ties to WikiLeaks, following similar moves by the e-commerce Web site Amazon and the domain name company EveryDNS.net.

byline.original: By JOHN F. BURNS; Ravi Somaiya contributed reporting

lead_paragraph: Julian Assange and WikiLeaks have been jettisoned to fame or notoriety (choose your noun, please) not because of a passing political battle but for reasons much deeper: the desire to possess, distribute and devour information. Ever since the release in July this year of some 92,000 documents relating to America's involvement in Afghanistan, an old joke from Communist times keeps spinning around my head. ''We cannot predict the future,'' announces the newsreader of Soviet radio reporting on the Politburo's deliberations, ''but the past is changing before our very eyes.'' Now our understanding of the nature of the intervention in Iraq has also changed radically with the publication of a still more astonishing collection of 391,832 secret United States military field reports from the kaleidoscopic theaters of battle. It has been the eye-opening, game-changing year of WikiLeaks. It started in April, with the release of video shot in 2007 from an Apache helicopter as a group of men on open ground in Baghdad were fired upon. Two of the victims worked for Reuters, as a photographer and driver, and the tragic nature of their deaths was made all the more horrific by the robotic, almost desultory voices of the airmen narrating their actions. The impact was immense. Julian Assange, WikiLeaks' mercurial and complicated founder, had the attention of the world.

headline.main: The Gift of Information

abstract: Misha Glenny The Gifts of 2010 column on Julian Assange and WikiLeaks's dissemination of classified information; photo (M)
snippet: Julian Assange and WikiLeaks have been jettisoned to fame or notoriety (choose your noun, please) not because of a passing political battle but for reasons much deeper: the desire to possess, distribute and devour information. Ever since the release...

lead_paragraph: I READ the Monday New York Times with what can only be described as a sinking feeling. Here on display, based on yet another WikiLeaks release, was the breathtaking disclosure of American diplomats' highly sensitive internal communications about friends and enemies. The discreet world of confidential embassy cables had seemingly been blown apart.

headline.main: What if the Secrets Stayed Secret?

abstract: Arthur S Brisbane Public Editor column examines the decision by the New York Times to publish documents released by WikiLeaks (M)
snippet: The clear case for publishing the diplomatic cables released by WikiLeaks.

lead_paragraph: LONDON -- The battle lines between supporters of the whistle-blowing Web site WikiLeaks and its detractors began to form on Sunday, as supporters erected numerous copies of the site on the Internet and the United States put pressure on Switzerland not to offer a haven to the site's founder, Julian Assange. Since several major Internet companies cut off services to WikiLeaks in recent days, activists have created hundreds of mirror sites, Web sites that host exact copies of another site's content, making censorship difficult.

headline.main: With Help From Internet Pirates, Hundreds of Copies of WikiLeaks Site Appear

abstract: Battle lines between supporters of WikiLeaks and its detractors begin to form, as supporters erect numerous copies of Web site on Internet and United States pressures Switzerland not to offer haven to site's founder Julian Assange (M)
snippet: The United States urged Switzerland not to provide safe haven for the site’s founder, who was accepting donations to a bank account there.

lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON -- Julian Assange, the beleaguered founder of the anti-secrecy group WikiLeaks, has threatened to release many more confidential diplomatic cables if legal action is taken against him or his organization. Mr. Assange's threat poses a problem for the Obama administration as it explores ways to prosecute Mr. Assange or the group. On Monday, as Mr. Assange's lawyers said he would meet with the British police about criminal charges involving sexual encounters in Sweden, Attorney General Eric H. Holder Jr. said the Justice Department had ''a very serious, active, ongoing investigation that is criminal in nature'' into the WikiLeaks matter.

headline.main: Founder of WikiLeaks Warns That He Could Release More Secret Dispatches

abstract: Julian Assange, beleaguered founder of anti-secrecy group WikiLeaks, is threatening to release many more confidential diplomatic cables if legal action is taken against him or his organization (M)
snippet: Julian Assange said that he would release all 251,287 cables if legal action were taken against him.

byline.original: By SCOTT SHANE; Charlie Savage and Brian Knowlton contributed reporting from Washington, and Ravi Somaiya from London

lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON -- The Justice Department, in considering whether and how it might indict Julian Assange, is looking beyond the Espionage Act of 1917 to other possible offenses, including conspiracy or trafficking in stolen property, according to officials familiar with the investigation. Attorney General Eric H. Holder Jr. acknowledged this week that there were problems with the Espionage Act, a World War I-era law that says the unauthorized possession and dissemination of information related to national defense is illegal. But he also hinted that prosecutors were looking at other statutes with regard to Mr. Assange, the founder of WikiLeaks.

headline.main: U.S. Prosecutors, Weighing WikiLeaks Charges, Hit the Law Books

abstract: Justice Department, in considering whether and how it might indict WikiLeaks founder Julian Assange, is looking beyond Espionage Act of 1917 to other possible offenses, including conspiracy or trafficking in stolen property; photo (M
snippet: Espionage is only one of the possible charges being considered by prosecutors looking into the WikiLeaks case.

lead_paragraph: LONDON -- After months of posting troves of classified American documents on the Internet, Julian Assange, founder of the WikiLeaks Web site, surrendered to British authorities and was jailed on Tuesday after a judge reviewing a Swedish extradition request found him to be a flight risk and denied him bail. For Mr. Assange and his supporters, as well as for those who have condemned him for the brazen leak of American secrets, there was a bizarre twist in the fast-moving events at a London courthouse. Instead of being arrested for punching a gaping hole in the secret worlds of American military and diplomatic power, an outcome he has long predicted, Mr. Assange, a 39-year-old Australian, found himself ensnared in allegations stemming from brief sexual encounters this summer with two young Swedish women.

headline.main: WikiLeaks Founder Is Jailed In Britain in Swedish Assault

abstract: Julian Assange, founder of Wikileaks Web site, surrenders to British authorities and is jailed after judge reviewing Swedish extradition request finds him to be flight risk and denies bail; charges against him stem from allegations over brief sexual encounters with two young Swedish women; it is bizarre twist for Assange, his supporters and those who have condemned him for brazen leak of classified American documents; his arrest on Swedish charges might affect Obama administration's continuing deliberations about how, or whether to charge him for publicized leaks; it is also unclear whether Assange will follow through on his past threats to retaliate for an arrest by releasing new batch of secret information; photos (M)
snippet: Julian Assange, the founder of WikiLeaks, said he would resist extradition to Sweden, where he faces questioning in connection with alleged sex offenses.

byline.original: By JOHN F. BURNS and RAVI SOMAIYA; Reporting was contributed by Scott Shane, Charlie Savage and Brian Knowlton from Washington, and Ravi Somaiya from London

lead_paragraph: FORWARD OPERATING BASE, CONNOLLY, Afghanistan -- Defense Secretary Robert M. Gates on Tuesday applauded the arrest of Julian Assange, the founder of WikiLeaks, whose Web site has released hundreds of thousands of classified military and diplomatic documents and become a scourge of the Pentagon. Told of Mr. Assange's arrest by reporters traveling with him on a trip to Afghanistan, Mr. Gates said, ''I hadn't heard that, but that sounds like good news to me.''

headline.main: Gates Calls Assange Arrest 'Good News'

snippet: The defense secretary, speaking in Afghanistan on Monday, applauded the arrest of the founder of WikiLeaks.

lead_paragraph: LONDON -- In a campaign that had some declaring the start of a ''cyberwar,'' hundreds of Internet activists mounted retaliatory attacks on Wednesday on the Web sites of multinational companies and other organizations they deemed hostile to the WikiLeaks antisecrecy organization and its jailed founder, Julian Assange. Within 12 hours of a British judge's decision on Tuesday to deny Mr. Assange bail in a Swedish extradition case, attacks on the Web sites of WikiLeaks's ''enemies,'' as defined by the organization's impassioned supporters around the world, caused several corporate Web sites to become inaccessible or slow down markedly.

headline.main: Hackers Attack Sites Considered WikiLeaks Foes

abstract: Hundreds of Internet activists attack Web sites of multinational companies that took action against Wikileaks; within 12 hours of British judge's decision to deny WikiLeaks founder Julian Assange bail in Swedish extradition case, attacks cause several corporate Web sites to become inaccessible or slow down markedly; targets of attacks include MasterCard, which had stopped processing donations for Wikileaks; Amazon.com, which revoked use of its computer servers; and PayPal, which stopped accepting donations for WikiLeaks (M)
snippet: Activists attacked sites of companies like Mastercard that took action against WikiLeaks; a counterattack on hackers’ sites followed.

byline.original: By JOHN F. BURNS and RAVI SOMAIYA; John Markoff and Ashlee Vance contributed reporting from San Francisco

lead_paragraph: They got their start years ago as cyberpranksters, an online community of tech-savvy kids more interested in making mischief than political statements. But the coordinated attacks on major corporate and government Web sites in defense of WikiLeaks, which began on Wednesday and continued on Thursday, suggested that the loosely organized group called Anonymous might have come of age, evolving into one focused on more serious matters: in this case, the definition of Internet freedom.

headline.main: Web Attackers Point to Cause In WikiLeaks

abstract: Coordinated attacks on major corporate and government Web sites in defense of WikiLeaks suggest that loosely organized group called Anonymous might be evolving into one more focused on defining Internet freedom; attacks on such behemoths as MasterCard, Visa and PayPal are not nearly as sophisticated as some less publicized assaults but are still step forward in group's larger battle against what it sees as increasing control of Internet by corporations and governments; lawyer for WikiLeaks founder Julian Assange says he strongly denies that he encouraged attacks; photo (M)
snippet: Loosely united Internet pranksters have evolved into a political movement for an unfettered Internet.

byline.original: By NOAM COHEN; Reporting was contributed by John Markoff and Ashlee Vance from San Francisco, Ravi Somaiya from London and Marlise Simons from Paris

lead_paragraph: LONDON -- Julian Assange, the jailed founder of the anti-secrecy group WikiLeaks, was ordered freed on $315,000 bail on Tuesday but remained at least temporarily in custody awaiting a final decision on whether he will be extradited to Sweden over allegations of sexual offenses against two women. Mr. Assange was driven back to Wandsworth Prison in London on Tuesday night, past cheering and whistling supporters and scores of flashbulbs, pending an appeal of the bail ruling by the Swedish authorities, which must be heard at Britain's High Court within the next 48 hours.

headline.main: Founder of WikiLeaks Is Ordered Freed on Bail

abstract: WikiLeaks founder Julian Assange, who is in jail on sexual offense charges against two women in Sweden, is ordered released on $315,000 bail in London, England; he remains temporarily in custody as he awaits final decision on whether he will be extradited to Sweden for trial (M)
snippet: Julian Assange was ordered released on $310,000 bail as he challenges a Swedish prosecutor’s demand for his extradition but remained in custody pending appeal.

byline.original: By RAVI SOMAIYA; Alan Cowell contributed reporting from Berlin, and J. David Goodman from New York

lead_paragraph: If Ben Bernanke were an investor, he'd be disappointed . The first chunk of the Federal Reserve's $600 billion Treasury bond purchase program is in the red, thanks to rising yields. The central bank's cheap financing makes outright losses unlikely, but Mr. Bernanke, the Fed chairman, could still face an image problem.

headline.main: Rising Rates And Fed's Red Ink

abstract: Reuters BreakingViews column observes first chunk of Federal Reserve's $600 billion Treasury bond purchase program is in the red, due to rising yields; holds its cheap financing makes outright losses unlikely, but notes that Fed chairman Ben S Bernanke could still face image problem; draws parallels between Facebook founder Mark Zuckerberg and WikiLeaks leader Julian Assange; observes each is leading technological assault on privacy, although with differences in scale and intent; photo (M)
snippet: The first portion of the Federal Reserve’s $600 billion Treasury bond-buying program is in the red, causing an image problem for Ben Bernanke.

byline.original: By AGNES T. CRANE and ROBERT CYRAN

lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON -- Federal prosecutors, seeking to build a case against the WikiLeaks leader Julian Assange for his role in a huge dissemination of classified government documents, are looking for evidence of any collusion in his early contacts with an Army intelligence analyst suspected of leaking the information. Justice Department officials are trying to find out whether Mr. Assange encouraged or even helped the analyst, Pfc. Bradley Manning, to extract classified military and State Department files from a government computer system. If he did so, they believe they could charge him as a conspirator in the leak, not just as a passive recipient of the documents who then published them.

headline.main: Building Case For Conspiracy By WikiLeaks

abstract: Prosecutors trying to build case against WikiLeaks founder Julian Assange for his role in release of classified documents are seeking evidence that he helped acquire government files; Justice Department officials are trying to find out whether Assange encouraged or helped Private Bradley Manning, Army intelligence analyst suspected of leaking information about Afghanistan war, to extract classified military and State Department files from government computer system; prosecutors could then charge Assange as conspirator in leak, not just passive recipient of documents who then published them (M)
snippet: WASHINGTON -- Federal prosecutors, seeking  to build a case against the WikiLeaks leader Julian Assange for his role in a huge dissemination of classified government documents, are looking for evidence of any collusion in his early contacts with an...

keywords.name: subject
keywords.value: UNITED STATES DEFENSE AND MILITARY FORCES

lead_paragraph: LONDON -- Julian Assange, the founder of WikiLeaks, was released from jail on $315,000 bail on Thursday, and he vowed in a defiant speech to continue to release classified documents and to fight extradition to Sweden for questioning about accusations of sexual offenses. After nine days in Wandsworth Prison, Mr. Assange emerged into an explosion of photographers' flashbulbs and spotlights under the grand arch of the Royal Courts of Justice. ''Well, it's great to feel the fresh air of London again,'' he told a cheering crowd.

headline.main: Freed on Bail, WikiLeaks Founder Offers Defiant Note

abstract: WikiLeaks founder Julian Assange is released from London jail on $315,000 bail, and vows in defiant speech to continue to release classified documents and to fight extradition to Sweden for questioning about accusations of sexual offenses; photo (M)
snippet: Julian Assange emerged from custody on Thursday after the High Court in London granted him bail while he fights extradition.

byline.original: By RAVI SOMAIYA; Alan Cowell contributed reporting from Paris, and J. David Goodman from New York

lead_paragraph: LONDON -- Julian Assange, the founder of WikiLeaks who was released from a British jail late last week, is facing a new challenge: the leak of a 68-page confidential Swedish police report that sheds new light on the allegations of sexual misconduct that led to Mr. Assange's legal troubles. The Swedish report traces events over a four-day period in August when Mr. Assange, a 39-year-old Australian, had what he has described as consensual sexual relationships with two Swedish women. Their accounts, which form the basis of an extradition case against Mr. Assange, state that their encounters with him began consensually, but became nonconsensual when he persisted in having unprotected sex with them in defiance of their insistence that he use a condom.

headline.main: Confidential Swedish Police Report Details Allegations Against WikiLeaks Founder

abstract: Leaked Swedish police report describes four-day period when WikiLeaks founder Julian Assange allegedly had sexual encounters with Swedish women that became nonconsensual; Assange's supporters say allegations are part of American vendetta following WikiLeaks' publication of classified documents, but reports suggest Swedish case may not be as flawed as they charge; photos (M)
snippet: The leak of a police report sheds light on alleged sexual misconduct that led to legal troubles for Julian Assange, the founder of WikiLeaks.

byline.original: By JOHN F. BURNS and RAVI SOMAIYA; Christina Anderson contributed reporting from Stockholm

lead_paragraph: ''Tens of thousands of its internal documents will be exposed on Wikileaks.org with no polite requests for executives' response or other forewarnings.'' That was according to Forbes magazine, which interviewed Julian Assange, the founder of WikiLeaks, last month. The excerpt sparked a global cacophony of speculation that a bank - perhaps Bank of America - may be the next target of the inscrutable ''high-tech terrorist.'' (Such was Vice President Joseph R. Biden's description of Mr. Assange over the weekend.)

headline.main: A WikiLeaks Problem For Enforcers

abstract: Andrew Ross Sorkin Dealbook column on speculation following Times of London interview with Julian Assange that bank, possibly Bank of America, may be next target of release of internal documents by WikiLeaks; holds that while on surface it may seem that bank in question should fear documents, it may be regulators in Washington, including Securities and Exchange Commission, that have more to fear by their release; posits that while e-mail and other documents from financial institutions could be viewed as treasure trove for regulators to scrutinize, they could also reveal information that was either not uncovered or ignored, both scenarios which would be embarrassing and damaging to United States which has spent millions of dollars investigating Wall Street in recent years (M)
snippet: ''Tens of thousands of its internal documents will be exposed on Wikileaks.org with no polite requests for executives' response or other forewarnings.''     That was according to Forbes magazine, which interviewed Julian Assange, the founder of...

lead_paragraph: BUNGAY, England -- When Julian Assange wakes these days, he looks out from a three-story Georgian mansion house overlooking a man-made lake. Under a blanket of snow, the 650-acre Ellingham Hall estate, a mile back from the closest public road, is as tranquil a spot as can be found in eastern England. But Mr. Assange, the WikiLeaks founder, who is fighting accusations of sexual misconduct in Sweden, strolls through this bucolic idyll with an electronic tag on his ankle and a required daily 20-minute drive to the part-time police station in the neighboring town of Beccles. There he signs a register and chats ''pleasantly'' with the officers, according to their account, and returns to his curfew at the hall.

headline.main: Under 'High-Tech House Arrest,' WikiLeaks Founder Takes the Offensive

abstract: Wikileaks founder Julian Assange, who is fighting accusations of sexual misconduct in Sweden, holds press conference in England where he is under house arrest; he continues to cast himself as victim of smear campaign led by United States, which is weighing criminal prosecution; photo (M)
snippet: Julian Assange continues to cast himself as the victim of a smear campaign led by the United States, which is weighing criminal prosecution for his organization’s leaks.

byline.original: By JOHN F. BURNS and RAVI SOMAIYA; Scott Shane contributed reporting from Washington

lead_paragraph: By the time the conference call ended, it was nearly midnight at Bank of America's headquarters in Charlotte, N.C., but the bank's counterespionage work was only just beginning. A day earlier, on Nov. 29, the director of WikiLeaks, Julian Assange, said in an interview that he intended to ''take down'' a major American bank and reveal an ''ecosystem of corruption'' with a cache of data from an executive's hard drive. With Bank of America's share price falling on the widely held suspicion that the hard drive was theirs, the executives on the call concluded it was time to take action.

headline.main: Facing a New Type of Threat From WikiLeaks, a Bank Plays Defense

abstract: Bank of America is conducting broad internal investigation of thousands of documents, prompted by statement by WikiLeaks director Julian Assange, who said that he intended to take down a major American bank and reveal 'ecosystem of corruption'; it is looking for any sign that its systems might have been compromised and is widely suspected to target of latest WikiLeaks probe; photos (M)
snippet: Since WikiLeaks threatened to “take down” a major American bank, Bank of America has been hunting for signs that its systems have been compromised.

byline.original: By NELSON D. SCHWARTZ; Eric Dash and Louise Story contributed reporting

lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON -- The State Department is warning hundreds of human rights activists, foreign government officials and businesspeople identified in leaked diplomatic cables of potential threats to their safety and has moved a handful of them to safer locations, administration officials said Thursday. The operation, which involves a team of 30 in Washington and embassies from Afghanistan to Zimbabwe, reflects the administration's fear that the disclosure of cables obtained by the organization WikiLeaks has damaged American interests by exposing foreigners who supply valuable information to the United States.

headline.main: U.S. Cautions People Named In Cable Leaks

abstract: State Department is warning hundreds of human rights activists, foreign government officials and businesspeople identified in leaked diplomatic cables of potential threats to their safety and has moved handful of them to safer locations; operation reflects Obama administration's fear that disclosure of cables obtained by Wikileaks has damaged American interests by exposing foreigners who supply valuable information to United States; State Department is mainly concerned about cables that have yet to be leaked; say as cables continue to trickle out, protecting those identified will be complex, delicate and long-term undertaking (M)
snippet: Officials say hundreds of rights activists, foreign officials and businesspeople have been warned of potential threats.

keywords.name: subject
keywords.value: HUMAN RIGHTS AND HUMAN RIGHTS VIOLATIONS

byline.original: By MARK LANDLER and SCOTT SHANE

lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON -- Prosecutors investigating the disclosure of thousands of classified government documents by the anti-secrecy group WikiLeaks have gone to court to demand the Twitter account activity of several people linked to the organization, including its founder, Julian Assange, according to the group and a copy of a subpoena made public late Friday. The subpoena is the first public evidence of a criminal investigation, announced last month by Attorney General Eric H. Holder Jr., that has been urged on by members of Congress of both parties but is fraught with legal and political difficulties for the Obama administration. It was denounced by WikiLeaks, which has so far made public only about 1 percent of the quarter-million confidential diplomatic cables in its possession but has threatened to post them all on the Web if criminal charges are brought.

headline.main: TWITTER RECORDS IN WIKILEAKS CASE ARE SUBPOENAED

abstract: Prosecutors investigating the disclosure of thousands of classified government documents by the anti-secrecy group WikiLeaks have subpoenaed the Twitter account activity of several people linked to the organization, including its founder Julian Assange; subpoena is the first public evidence of a criminal investigation; photos (M)
snippet: The subpoena is the first public evidence to surface of a criminal investigation of disclosures of classified information by WikiLeaks and its founder.

byline.original: By SCOTT SHANE and JOHN F. BURNS; Scott Shane reported from Washington, and John F. Burns from London. Reporting was contributed by Ravi Somaiya from London, Claire Cain Miller and Miguel Helft from San Francisco, Eric Lipton from Washington, and J. David Goodman from New York

lead_paragraph: LONDON -- Lawyers for Julian Assange, the founder of the WikiLeaks antisecrecy group, said on Tuesday that they would oppose his extradition to Sweden because he might subsequently face ''illegal rendition'' to the United States, risking imprisonment at Guantánamo Bay, Cuba, or even the death penalty. They made the assertion in defense documents released after Mr. Assange made a brief appearance in a British high-security court for a largely procedural hearing concerning his resistance to demands for his extradition to Sweden, where he has been accused of sexual misconduct.

headline.main: WikiLeaks Founder Said to Fear 'Illegal Rendition' to U.S.

abstract: Lawyers for Julian Assange, founder of the Wikileaks antisecrecy group, say they will oppose his extradition from Britain to Sweden because he might subsequently face 'illegal rendition' to United States in connection with publication of thousands of confidential State Department documents; he is facing sexual misconduct charges in Sweden; photo (M)
snippet: Lawyers for Julian Assange said they would argue against a demand for the WikiLeaks founder’s extradition to Sweden on the grounds that he might later face “illegal rendition” to the United States.

byline.original: By RAVI SOMAIYA and ALAN COWELL; Ravi Somaiya reported from London, and Alan Cowell from Paris

lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON -- Julian Assange, the flamboyant founder of WikiLeaks, is living on a supporter's 600-acre estate outside London, where he has negotiated $1.7 million in book deals and regularly issues defiant statements about the antisecrecy group's plans. Meanwhile, the young soldier accused of leaking the secret documents that brought WikiLeaks and Mr. Assange to fame and notoriety is locked in a tiny cell at the Quantico Marine Corps Base in Virginia. The soldier, Pfc. Bradley Manning, who turned 23 last month in the military prison, is accused of the biggest leak of classified documents in American history. He awaits trial on charges that could put him in prison for 52 years, according to the Army.

headline.main: Accused Soldier Stays in Brig As WikiLeaks Link Is Sought

abstract: Supporters of Pfc Bradley Manning, soldier accused of leaking secret documents to WikiLeaks, are concerned he is being treated unfairly; Manning is locked in tiny cell at Quantico Marine Corps Base in Virginia, while WikiLeaks founder Julian Assange is living on supporter's 600-acre estate; while members of Congress denounce both men's actions as criminal, Justice Department is still looking for charge it can press against Assange; experts say one approach is to link two men in conspiracy to disclose classified material; military rejects accusations that Manning is being mistreated; photo (M)
snippet: WASHINGTON -- Julian Assange, the flamboyant founder of WikiLeaks, is living on a supporter's 600-acre estate outside London, where he has negotiated $1.7 million in book deals and regularly issues defiant statements about the antisecrecy group's...

keywords.name: subject
keywords.value: UNITED STATES DEFENSE AND MILITARY FORCES

lead_paragraph: LONDON -- A former senior Swiss bank executive said on Monday that he had given the WikiLeaks founder, Julian Assange, details of more than 2,000 prominent individuals and companies that he contends engaged in tax evasion and other possible criminal activity. Rudolf M. Elmer, who ran the Caribbean operations of the Swiss bank Julius Baer for eight years until he was dismissed in 2002, refused to identify any of the individuals or companies, but he told reporters at a news conference that about 40 politicians and ''pillars of society'' were among them.

headline.main: Ex-Banker Gives Data On Taxes To Web Site

abstract: Rudolf M Elmer, former executive at Swiss bank Julius Baer, at press conference, hands WikiLeaks founder Julian Assange disk containing details of more than 2,000 prominent individuals and companies that he contends engaged in tax evasion and other possible criminal activity; conference is first major public event Assange has held since arrest in London; photo (M)
snippet: A former executive with Julius Baer said he had given details of more than 2,000 individuals and companies.

byline.original: By RAVI SOMAIYA and JULIA WERDIGIER

lead_paragraph: This past June, Alan Rusbridger, the editor of The Guardian, phoned me and asked, mysteriously, whether I had any idea how to arrange a secure communication. Not really, I confessed. The Times doesn't have encrypted phone lines, or a Cone of Silence. Well then, he said, he would try to speak circumspectly. In a roundabout way, he laid out an unusual proposition: an organization called WikiLeaks, a secretive cadre of antisecrecy vigilantes, had come into possession of a substantial amount of classified United States government communications. WikiLeaks's leader, Julian Assange, an eccentric former computer hacker of Australian birth and no fixed residence, offered The Guardian half a million military dispatches from the battlefields of Afghanistan and Iraq. There might be more after that, including an immense bundle of confidential diplomatic cables. The Guardian suggested -- to increase the impact as well as to share the labor of handling such a trove -- that The New York Times be invited to share this exclusive bounty. The source agreed. Was I interested? I was interested.

headline.main: THE  BOY  WHO  KICKED  THE  HORNET'S  NEST

abstract: Bill Keller article explains how the New York Times began working with Wikileaks, why it published the the classified documents and what interactions with Julian Assange was like; drawings (L)
snippet: Is Julian Assange, the WikiLeaks founder, a puppet master of the news media? He would like you to think so. But The Times’s dealings with him reveal a different story.

keywords.name: subject
keywords.value: UNITED STATES DEFENSE AND MILITARY FORCES

lead_paragraph: LONDON -- As the WikiLeaks founder Julian Assange fights extradition to Sweden to face allegations of sexual wrongdoing, a dozen of his former colleagues are creating an alternative Web site for leaks to be governed by what they characterize as a revised vision of radical transparency. The new organization, OpenLeaks, will begin work in earnest this summer, said Herbert Snorrason, an Icelandic programmer who is involved. It aims, he said, to avoid the ''influence of a single figurehead'' by refusing to handle documents itself. Instead, it will act as a neutral conduit to connect leakers with media and human rights organizations.

headline.main: Former WikiLeaks Colleagues Forming New Web Site, OpenLeaks

abstract: Former colleagues of WikiLeaks founder Julian Assange are creating an alternative Web site called OpenLeaks, which will be governed by what they characterize as a revised vision of radical transparency; photo (M)
snippet: The new site emerges from the ashes of a struggle between Julian Assange, the WikiLeaks founder, and many of his closest associates.

lead_paragraph: LONDON -- Lawyers for the WikiLeaks founder, Julian Assange, said at a court hearing on Monday that they thought he would not receive a fair trial if he was extradited to Sweden to face accusations of sexual misconduct. The hearing, scheduled to continue on Tuesday, was the culmination of an acrimonious public battle with prosecutors in Sweden who have sought since September to question Mr. Assange, 39, about accusations made against him in Stockholm last summer by two women who volunteered for WikiLeaks, one in her early 30s and another in her mid-20s. One contends that he initiated unprotected sex with her while she was asleep, the morning after she had taken him to her apartment for the night.

headline.main: WikiLeaks Founder in Court to Fight Extradition Effort

abstract: WikiLeaks founder Julian Assange's hearing begins in London on extradition to Sweden to face accusations of sexual misconduct; photo (M)
snippet: The founder of WikiLeaks argued in a London court that extradition to Sweden could expose him to illegal rendition to the United States.

byline.original: By JOHN F. BURNS and RAVI SOMAIYA

lead_paragraph: LONDON -- Julian Assange, the WikiLeaks founder, said on Tuesday that the effort to extradite him to Sweden to face allegations of sexual misconduct represented a ''distortion of evidence and fact.'' Mr. Assange was speaking to reporters after the second day of a hearing that will determine whether he must return to Sweden, where prosecutors want to interrogate him about accusations made against him in Stockholm last summer by two women who had volunteered for WikiLeaks.

headline.main: In Extradition Hearing, Assange Says Prosecutors Distorted Facts

abstract: WikiLeaks founder Julian Assange tells press that efforts to extradite him from London to Sweden to face allegations of sexual misconduct represent a 'distortion of evidence and fact' (M)
snippet: The founder of WikiLeaks is arguing that extradition to Sweden could expose him to illegal rendition to the United States.

lead_paragraph: LONDON -- WikiLeaks said it was taking ''legal action'' over a tell-all book to be released Friday by a former staff member that is critical of its founder, Julian Assange, and says the Web site was disabled by a spate of defections last year. The former staff member, Daniel Domscheit-Berg, is a German computer scientist who was a prominent spokesman for WikiLeaks before falling out with Mr. Assange last summer. In ''Inside WikiLeaks: My Time With Julian Assange at the World's Most Dangerous Website,'' he writes of tensions between WikiLeaks' core members and Mr. Assange.

headline.main: WikiLeaks Angry About Former Staff Member's Book

abstract: WikiLeaks has taken legal action against former staffer Daniel Domscheit-Berg over his book that is set to be released; book, titled Inside WikiLeaks: My Time With Julian Assange at the World's Most Dangerous Website, exposes tensions between WikiLeaks core members and Assange, as well as details of Assange's leadership style, his paranoia and the way he managed WikiLeaks's finances; photo (M)
snippet: A tell-all book to be released Friday is highly critical of Julian Assange, and says the Web site was disabled by a spate of defections last year.

lead_paragraph: LONDON Lawyers for Julian Assange, the founder of WikiLeaks, said Friday that he should not be sent to Sweden to face allegations of sexual abuse there because he was now seen as ''public enemy number one'' in that country. Speaking on the final day of a contentious and hard-fought extradition hearing, Geoffrey Robertson, a lawyer for Mr. Assange, told a court that comments this week by the Swedish prime minister, Fredrik Reinfeldt, meant that his client could not get a fair trial.

headline.main: Britain: Definition of Rape at Issue As Assange Hearing Closes

abstract: Lawyers for Julian Assange, founder of Wikileaks, suggest that he cannot get fair trial if extradited to Sweden and that encounters leading to accusations of sexual wrongdoing by two women in Stockholm could not be universally classified as crimes (S)
snippet: Lawyers for the founder of WikiLeaks said Friday that he should not be sent to Sweden because he was now seen as “public enemy number one” in that country.

lead_paragraph: LONDON -- Julian Assange, the WikiLeaks founder, must be extradited to Sweden to face accusations of sexual abuse, a British court ordered Thursday. Mr. Assange immediately said he would appeal the decision. Judge Howard Riddle took just over an hour to issue a sweeping dismissal of the defense team's arguments -- from arcane technical points to dark suggestions that Mr. Assange would not receive a fair trial in Sweden and might even face extradition to the United States, imprisonment at the Guantánamo Bay, Cuba, prison and possibly death.

headline.main: British Court Grants Sweden's Request for Extradition of the Founder of WikiLeaks

abstract: British court orders Julian Assange, founder of WikiLeaks, be extradited to Sweden to face accusations of sexual abuse; he plans to appeal (M)
snippet: A British court on Thursday ordered Julian Assange, the WikiLeaks founder, to be extradited to Sweden to face accusations of sexual abuse. He has 7 days to appeal the ruling.

byline.original: By RAVI SOMAIYA; Richard Berry contributed reporting from Paris

lead_paragraph: LONDON -- A report published by a British magazine on Tuesday said the WikiLeaks founder, Julian Assange, suggested that British journalists, including the editor of The Guardian, were engaged in a Jewish-led conspiracy to smear his organization. His remarks appeared in the magazine Private Eye, in an article by its editor, Ian Hislop, who outlined a rambling phone call that Mr. Assange made on Feb. 16 to complain about the coverage of WikiLeaks.

headline.main: Assange Cited Jewish Plot, Report Says

abstract: British magazine Private Eye prints remarks from Wikileaks founder Julian Assange suggesting that British journalists, including the editor of The Guardian, are engaged in a Jewish conspiracy to smear his organization; Assange claims magazine had grossly distorted or misremembered his comments (M)
snippet: The WikiLeaks founder suggested that British journalists were engaged in a “Jewish” conspiracy to smear his organization.

lead_paragraph: Charles Fergusonhas taken on his first nondocumentary project with HBO Films, directing a movie about Julian Assange, the founder of WikiLeaks, according to The Hollywood Reporter. Mr. Ferguson won an Oscar this year for his documentary ''Inside Job,'' about the origins of the 2008 financial crisis, and received a nomination for his 2007 film ''No End In Sight,'' about the American occupation in Iraq. Mr. Assange has been embroiled in controversy since November, when WikiLeaks made public confidential diplomatic cables from the State Department. Shortly afterward, he was arrested in Britain on charges of sexual abuse in Sweden; he has appealed a decision allowing his extradition to Sweden. He is also under investigation by the United States Justice Department. Other films about Mr. Assange, below, and WikiLeaks are in the works, The Los Angeles Times reported. DreamWorks has optioned several memoirs about Mr. Assange and WikiLeaks; Universal has a documentary by Alex Gibney(''Enron: The Smartest Guys in the Room'') in production; and Annapurna Productions has said it is financing a film to be produced, and possibly written by, Mark Boal, whose ''Hurt Locker'' won him two Oscars in 2009, for original screenplay and best film.

headline.main: Ferguson to Direct Film About WikiLeaks Founder

abstract: Several films are in the works about WikiLeaks founder Julian Assange, including one by director Charles Ferguson; photo (S)
snippet: Charles Ferguson has taken on his first nondocumentary project with HBO Films, directing a movie about Julian Assange, the founder of WikiLeaks, according to The Hollywood Reporter.

lead_paragraph: A book deal that Julian Assange, the founder of WikiLeaks, signed only six months ago has fallen through, according to a report in The Guardian on Wednesday, but Canongate, his publisher in Britain, said it was still expecting to publish the book. Canongate did not provide a date for its release, however. According to The Guardian report, Mr. Assange, left, had expressed concern that the memoir could be used against him by prosecutors in the United States. American officials have been weighing whether to try to charge Mr. Assange since WikiLeaks released a trove of State Department cables, but it is unclear where that effort stands. The book deal was announced in December; Mr. Assange said he expected to earn $1.7 million for the memoir, which was being ghostwritten by Andrew O'Hagan, a novelist. The memoir was originally scheduled for publication in April 2011 in Britain, although Mr. Assange's American publisher, Knopf, did not release a publication date. ''With projects like these, you never know about delivery, and you never know about timetables,'' said Paul Bogaards, a spokesman for Knopf, part of Random House. ''My understanding is that the book has been postponed.''

headline.main: WikiLeaks Memoir 'Postponed'

abstract: Book deal that WikiLeaks founder Julian Assange signed in December 2010 has fallen through due to Assange's concern that the memoir might be used against him by prosecutors in the United States; photo (M)
snippet: A book deal for Julian Assange, the founder of WikiLeaks, has reportedly fallen through over concerns the information could be used against him by United States prosecutors.

lead_paragraph: Julian Assange, the founder of WikiLeaks, returned to a British court on Tuesday in his fight against extradition to Sweden, where he has been accused of sexual abuse. Mr. Assange, left, nodded as his lawyers tried to persuade judges at the Royal Courts of Justice to overturn a previous decision that he return to Sweden to face the accusations, made by two women in Stockholm last year. Ben Emmerson, one of Mr. Assange's lawyers, said that his client's behavior in Sweden might have been ''disreputable, discourteous, disturbing,'' but that it did not constitute a crime under British law, rendering any Swedish arrest warrant invalid. The hearing will continue Wednesday.

headline.main: Britain: Assange Extradition Fight

abstract: WikiLeaks founder Julian Assange returns to British court in fight against extradition to Sweden, where he faces sex abuse charges; photo (S)
snippet: Julian Assange, the founder of WikiLeaks, returned to a British court on Tuesday in his fight against extradition to Sweden, where he has been accused of sexual abuse.

lead_paragraph: ELLINGHAM, England The man in the rubber boots and a thick coat to protect against the evening chill walked purposefully about a farm here, scattering pheasants as he went. He could have been an English gentleman out for a bit of hunting, except he carried no gun.

headline.main: WikiLeaks' Founder, In a Gilded British Cage

abstract: David Carr The Media Equation column observes WikiLeaks founder Julian Assange has taken refuge at a remote British country manor house belonging to videographer Vaughan Smith, far from the prying eyes of the mainstream press; photos (M)
snippet: WikiLeaks founder Julian Assange is more hunted than hunter these days, an itinerant with no permanent address save for a country manor provided by a former British journalist.
